tiles.headline: Berlin Head Office
tiles.text: The photo archive at the Berlin head office offers images on vase painting, sculpture, lamps and topography. Among the scholarly bequests are those of Th. Wiegand, O. Reuther, F. Noack, B. Schweitzer, G. Loeschke, A. Schiff, K. Ronczewski.

tiles.headline: Berlin Orient Department
tiles.text: Since 1998, the focus of the photographic collection has been on the documentation of own excavations in countries such as Ethiopia, Iraq, Yemen, Jordan, Lebanon, Oman, Saudi Arabia, Syria and eastern Turkey.

tiles.headline: Cairo Department
tiles.text: The photo archive of the Cairo Department focuses on the documentation of the department's excavations in Egypt. The archive comprises ca. 240,000 medium format (b/w, color) photographs, slides and 35mm-b/w-pictures.

tiles.headline: Damascus Branch
tiles.text: The photo archive of the branch owns around 45,000 negatives and slides from DAI research projects as well as of several important ruins in Syria that were documented as a part of a photographic survey. More than 40,000 digital images are archived.

tiles.headline: Istanbul Department
tiles.text: The photo archive is made up primarily of black-and-white photographs of Turkey, its population, architecture and archaeological artifacts. Its holdings consist of approx. 120,000 photos from the period 1880 - 2007, including 65,000 negative originals.

tiles.headline: Madrid Department
tiles.text: The archive holds ca. 50,500 photographs. It covers all archaeological art forms of the Iberian Peninsula from the beginning of time up to the Islamic period.

links.text: Sculpture Negatives of the DAI Rome

tiles.headline: Teheran Branch
tiles.text: The photo archive houses a large collection of photographs on Iranian archaeology and art history as well as documentation of excavation of the department in Bisutun, Bastam, Takht-i Suleiman, Zendan-i Suleiman and Firuzabad.

tiles.headline: Athens Department

link.text: External Link to Athens Department: A scientific legacy archive

tiles.text: Studies on the history of archaeology as well as on the history of academic institutions, such as the DAI, have demonstrated the importance of archival research and investigation of primary source material.

tiles.headline: Eurasia Department - Teheran Branch

link.text: External Link to Eurasia Department - Teheran Branch: Digitization of the archive

tiles.text: The Project TehranDigital has started the digitization of the archive of the Tehran Branch of the Eurasia Department of the German Archaeological Institute.

tiles.headline: Madrid Department

link.text: External Link to Madrid Department - Spanish Codices

tiles.text: The digital catalog of illuminated manuscripts of medieval Spain is based on an inventory of about 4,500 colored small image slides, located in the Madrid Department of the German Archaeological Institute (DAI).

tiles.headline: Rome Department

link.text: External Link to Rome Department: Historical drawings

tiles.text: Antiquity in drawings, maps and architectural surveys: primary documentary materials of the 19th and 20th century in the German Archaeological Institute at Rome.

tiles.headline: Rome Department

link.text: External Link to Rome Department: Correspondences

tiles.text: The drawings, aquarelles, maps, cross-sections, etc. of the two collections show ancient buildings and objects that document sites and finds that have been changed or destroyed in the course of the last years.

tiles.headline: Rome Department

link.text: External Link to Rome Department: Correspondences-Quarantine

tiles.text: Correspondence of Emil Braun and Eduard Gerhard during a cholera outbreak in 1836-1837

tiles.headline: Glass negatives within the framework of Emagines

link.text: Link to Glass negatives within the framework of Emagines

tiles.text: Within the project titled Emagines, glass negatives are being digitized with a long-term strategy and made accessible worldwide via the web-based database Arachne that is operated by the German Archaeological Institute and the CoDArchLab.

tiles.headline: Bequest of Friedrich Rakob

link.text: External Link to Bequest of Friedrich Rakob

tiles.text: Friedrich Rakob (1931-2007) was an architectural historian specialized in the architectural history of towns and cities in Northern Tunisia. Friedrich Rakobâs bequest includes a total of more than 63,000 photographic negatives, slides and contact prints as well as around 190 crates and folders.

tiles.headline: Friedrich Hinkel Archive of Sudan

link.text: External Link to Hinkel Archive of Sudan

tiles.text: The archive of Friedrich W. Hinkel represents one of the largest collections of research material concerning the archaeology of ancient Sudan.

tiles.headline: Scientific Legacy of Georg Kossack

link.text: External Link to Scientific Legacy of Georg Kossack

tiles.text: The integration of the archaeological material collection from the Kossack archive into existing datasets within the Arachne system allows a bidirectional connection between Kossack and the already existing data in Arachne.

tiles.headline: Scientific Legacy of Georg Steindorff

link.text: External Link to Scientific Legacy of Georg Steindorff

tiles.text: Steindorffâs diaries and letters always deal with the political processes in Germany, besides scientific questions.

tiles.headline: Syrian Heritage Archive Project

link.text: External Link to Syrian Heritage Archive

tiles.text: Implementation of a digital cultural heritage register for Syria in order to conserve cultural heritage in Syria, which is currently threatened by war.

tiles.headline: NARA
tiles.text: The aim of the âNorth African Research Archiveâ (NARA) is to provide a platform for archaeological cultural heritage from North Africa, in particular the Maghreb states of Tunisia, Algeria, Libya and Morocco.

tiles.headline: African Archaeological Archive Cologne

link.text: External Link to African Archaeological Archive Cologne

tiles.text: The African Archaeology Archive Cologne (AAArC) has made it a priority to digitize the present archieve documents and to make them accessible through the object database ARACHNE.

tiles.headline: Archive of Rhine-Westphalian Economy

link.text: External Link to to Archive of Rhine-Westphalian Economy

tiles.text: The negatives of the archive are depicting people in their working environments, productions techniques, machines and products, as well as industrial architecture or factories.

tiles.headline: The Photographic Collection of Max von Oppenheim

link.text: External Link to Collection of Max von Oppenheim

tiles.text: Max Freiherr von Oppenheim (1860-1946) was always accompanied by professional photographers when on his travels.The result was a collection of 13,000 photos that captured the life and culture of a world gone by.

tiles.headline: Munich Photo Library of the LMU

link.text: External Link to 'Munich Photo Library of the LMU'

tiles.text: The Institute of Classical Archaeology in Munich is home to a vast collection of photographs. Starting in 2016, digitization of this collection has been underway, with the results made open to the public via the Arachne database.

tiles.headline: Pergamon Altar Browser

link.text: External Link to 'Pergamon Altar browser: Pergamon Museum Berlin'

tiles.text: The image browser of the Pergamon Altar combines photographic recording of the frieze with the implementation into the online database ARACHNE.

tiles.headline: iDAI.objects/bookbrowser
tiles.text: As a part of ARACHNE, iDAI.books offers digital versions of books on classical studies published between the 16th and 19th century. Next to making the single book pages available to research in a broader sense as digital scans, they are also characterized and contextualized as well as digitally preserved.

tiles.headline: Trajan's Column Browser
tiles.text: By using a dedicated image browser, the Column of Trajan can now be researched in detail. Trajanâs Column is also contextualized to the entire contents of the Arachne.

tiles.headline: Ara Pacis Browser
tiles.text: The Ara Pacis Browser gives the opportunity to browse all relief panels of the monument.

tiles.headline: Al Idrisi - Archaeological Atlas of Algeria and Tunisia

link.text: External Link to 'Al Idrisi - Archaeological Atlas of Algeria and Tunisia'

tiles.text: Geoserver of Algeria and Tunisia that has been mapped within the project Al Idrisi as a combination of the Atlas archÃ©ologique de l'AlgÃ©rie and the Atlas archÃ©ologique de la Tunesie.

tiles.headline: Lead Ingots from Shipwrecks (Bizerte)

link.text: External Link to 'Lead Ingots from Shipwrecks (Bizerte)'

tiles.text: Geoserver showing lead ingots that come from shipwrecks from the western Mediterranean.

tiles.headline: Palmyra-GIS
tiles.text: With the application Palmyra-GIS and the corresponding 3D print of the terrain model of the ancient Syrian city of ruins Palmyra, researchers want to contribute to the protection of the world heritage from the war in Syria.

tiles.headline: Palmyra Digital Atlas
tiles.text: Geoserver of Palmyra showing known structures and topography. Compilation of the antique polygon and line features from the Mapset Topographia Palmyrena.

tiles.headline: Triphylia - Map of a Greek landscape

link.text: Triphylia - Map of a Greek landscape'

tiles.text: Geoserver of the Greek landscape of Triphylia that shows soils, terrain, settlements, rivers, etc.

tiles.headline: Roman Chronology
tiles.text: A web service that connects period terms to dating and all kinds of material objects, geodata and textual data.

tiles.headline: Ancient Egyptian Chronology
tiles.text: A web service connecting ancient Egyptian period terms to actual dating.

tiles.headline: European Bronze Age Chronology

link.text: External Link to 'European bronze age chronology'

tiles.text: A web service connecting period terms of the European Bronze Age to actual dating.

tiles.headline: Geological Time Scale
tiles.text: A web service connecting the geological time terms to actual dating.

tiles.headline: Prussian Monuments in the Province of Brandenburg/Berlin
tiles.text: A DFG-project that aimed at documenting all built heritage sites in Brandenburg/Berlin between 1860/70 and 1918.

tiles.headline: Clarac, MusÃ©e du Sculpture
tiles.text: The exploration of ancient sculpture before the middle of the 19th century as portrayed in Claracâs 'MusÃ©e de sculpture antique et moderne'.

tiles.headline: 1836 - Emil Braun and the first library catalog

link.text: 1836 - Emil Braun and the first library catalogue

tiles.text: A digitized viewer of Emil Braunâs first library catalog from 1836 that is available through Arachne.

tiles.headline: Online Coins of the Roman Empire (contains AFE)

link.text: External Link to 'Online coins of the roman empire, (OCRE contains AFE)'

tiles.text: A tool designed to help in the identification, cataloging, and research of the rich and varied coinage of the Roman Empire. The project records every published type of Roman Imperial coinage from Augustus in 31 BC, until the death of Zeno in AD 491.

tiles.headline: AFE

link.text: External Link to 'AFE (a part of OCRE)'

tiles.text: A joint project of Databases and Information Systems (DBIS) and the RÃ¶misch-Germanische Kommission (RGK) is investigating the logical integration of different coin find databases using ontologies.

tiles.headline: Reception of Antiquity in a Semantic Network

link.text: External Link to reception of antiquity in a semantic network

tiles.text: A reconstruction and online publication of about 1700 prints, which appeared between 1500 and 1900.

tiles.headline: Plaster Casts in Berlin

link.text: Plaster casts after greco-roman sculptures in Berlin

tiles.text: Every plaster cast in Berlin (from Freie UniversitÃ¤t, Humboldt-UniversitÃ¤t, and the Antikensammlung/State Museums of Berlin) representing an ancient object was systematically recorded and entered into ARACHNE.

tiles.headline: Digital Facsimiles of Historical Books

link.text: External Link to 'Digital Facsimiles of Historical Books'

tiles.text: The database compiles digital reproductions of historic illuminations in books and their cover pages in order to make them accessible to research.

tiles.headline: Sculptures in the Antikensammlung, Berlin
tiles.text: The complete catalog of sculptures in the Antikensammlung der Staatlichen Museen zu Berlin contains approximately 2,600 Greek, Cypriot, Etruscan, and Roman sculptures in stone, as well as several large bronzes.

tiles.headline: Plaster Cast Collection, University Bonn
tiles.text: The collection has been photographically documented and transferred into Arachne since 1998. That way the technical emphasis of the Archaeological Institutes of Cologne and Bonn can be brought closer together.

tiles.headline: Museo Maffeiano online-edition
tiles.text: Maffei published a book illustrating and describing various monuments in his collection, which is well suited for database-supported online-facsimile-edition. This online- aims to reflect a scientifically based preparation of the state of research.

tiles.headline: Schloss Fasanerie (Adolphseck) near Fulda
tiles.text: Among furniture, porcelain and paintings, Fasanerie Castle (Adolphseck) in Eichenzell near Fulda also features a collection of Greco-Roman sculpture, which was assembled by Landgrave Philipp of Hesse (1896-1980).

tiles.headline: Museum and Plaster Cast Collection, Leipzig

link.text: Museum and plaster cast collection, University Leipzig

tiles.text: The Museum of Antiquities of the Leipzig University is an archaeological teaching collection that contains plaster casts and originals of ancient art from the Mediterranean area.

tiles.headline: Plaster Cast Collection, Munich, LMU
tiles.text: The collection consists of more than 2000 casts and reproductions of sculptures, reliefs and small objects from Greek and Roman antiquity from the 7th century BC to the 5th century AD. The focus lies on Hellenistic sculpture and Roman portraits.

tiles.headline: Villa Wolkonsky, Antiquities Collection, Rome
tiles.text: The Villa Wolkonsky houses about 430 Roman antiquities collected from the beginning of the 19th-century. The Arachne collection contains the photographic documentation that was produced during the restoration project, some photographs from the historic collection.

tiles.headline: Plaster Cast Collection, University SaarbrÃ¼cken
tiles.text: The Institute of Classical Archaeology of the University of the Saarland possesses a small teaching collection containing originals of antiquities as well as plaster casts of ancient sculpture.

tiles.headline: Winckelmann-Society and Museum, Stendal

link.text: Collection of the Winckelmann-Society and Museum, Stendal

tiles.text: The inventory holds drawings, paintings, sculpture, antiques, coins and portrait medals as well as autographs and sketches. The integration of the collection into the online database ARACHNE is still ongoing.

tiles.headline: Archaeological Museum, Thessaloniki

link.text: Catalog of ancient sculpture, Archaeological Museum, Thessaloniki

tiles.text: The Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki keeps sculptures dating from the Archaic to the late Imperial period and found mainly in the area from various regions of Macedonia and Thrace.

tiles.headline: Corpus of Ancient Sarcophagi

link.text: External Link to 'Corpus of ancient sarcophagi'

tiles.text: The re-conception of the Corpus of Ancient Sarcophagi and from an IT point of view, assuming responsibility for backing up an online-presence of the material, which is to be as coherent as possible.

tiles.headline: Corpus Inscriptionum Latinarum (CIL)
tiles.text: The Corpus Inscriptionum Latinarum (CIL) is a comprehensive collection of ancient Latin inscriptions from all corners of the Roman Empire.

tiles.headline: Corpus of Minoan and Mycenaean Seals

link.text: External Link to 'Corpus of Minoan and Mycenaean Seals'

tiles.text: The projectâs aim is the scholarly publication of every preserved seal and clay cast from the Aegean Bronze Age. Most of the Corpus should be digitized, updated and available on the Internet for free before the project ends in 2011.

tiles.headline: Corpus of Roman Finds in the European Babaricum (CRFB)
FAAK 16: Paracas Archaeological Materials
tiles.text: The catalog provides data and images of archaeological finds and contexts which have been excavated since 1996 by the Nasca-Palpa Project.

tiles.headline: Siracusa - La cittÃ  e le sue mura
tiles.text: Studies on the Sicilian city of Syracuse

tiles.headline: Inden
tiles.text: A digital documentation of an excavation of the 1960s

tiles.headline: Antike Plastik 5.0.://
tiles.text: Media of documentation in archaeology

tiles.headline: Images and Imaginations of Roman Harbors

link.text: External Link to 'Images and Imaginations of Roman Harbors'

tiles.text: A publication regarding the documentation and contextualized analysis of depictions of Roman harbors using Arachne.

tiles.headline: The Basilica Aemilia on the Forum Romanum

link.text: External Link to 'The Basilica Aemilia on the Forum Romanum'

tiles.text: A publication on the Basilica Aemilia on the Forum Romanum as a focus of public life. A study of its remains, functions, and roles in Rome.

tiles.headline: Domestic Culture in Late Antique Ostia

link.text: Domestic Culture in Late Antique Ostia

tiles.text: A publication on the well-preserved remains of residential houses in the port city of Ostia that allow insights into the relationship of continuity and transformation between Imperial times and Late Antiquity.

tiles.headline: Sanctuaries in Kanatha
tiles.text: A publication on the Syrian city of Kanatha and its specific forms of sanctuaries in Hellenistic and Roman times and the coexistence of indigenous religions and the Roman state religion.

tiles.headline: Figurative Reception of Greek Poets and Philosophers

link.text: Figurative Reception of Greek Poets and Philosophers

tiles.text: A publication on a project that is researching the depictions of the discourse of Greek education by using different classes of material such as gems, cameos, lamps, reliefs.

tiles.headline: Roman Terracotta Masks
tiles.text: The project âTerracotta Masksâ is based on a dissertation about Roman Terracotta masks in the northwestern provinces conducted at the University of Cologne.

tiles.headline: Sea Creatures on Roman Sarcophagi
tiles.text: Publication on a work on the depiction of sea creatures on Roman sarcophagi with an online catalog showing new relevant pieces. The aim of the publication is to objectively re-evaluate previous assumptions.

tiles.headline: Dressed to Drill. Roman Centurions' Equipment

link.text: Dressed to Drill. Roman Centurions' Equipment

tiles.text: The publication compiles tombstones erected for centurions also depicting military equipment.

tiles.headline: Suermondt-Ludwig-Museum Aachen
tiles.text: The antiquities collection of the Suermondt-Ludwig-Museum in Aachen.

tiles.headline: ARIADNE
tiles.text: The goal was the integration of European archaeological repositories, which created a searchable catalog of datasets including unpublished reports, images, maps, databases and other kinds of archaeological information accessible online.

tiles.headline: CARARE
tiles.text: CARARE aims to advance professional practice and foster appreciation of digital archaeological and architectural heritage through the promotion for public benefit of digitization, connection. enhancement, and use of digital content.

tiles.headline: CeramEgypt
tiles.text: Pottery production and consumption in Ptolemaic-Roman Egypt based on pottery finds from surveys.

tiles.headline: EC-Chronoi: Multilingualism of Time
tiles.text: The project developed a tool that is able to normalize and detect time expressions in archaeological literature of varying source languages.

tiles.headline: Images in Pausanias
tiles.text: The purpose of the database âImages in Pausaniasâ is to systematically register all figurative works of art found in Pausanias and make them accessible for combined online research.

tiles.headline: Our Place: Our Place in the World
tiles.text: The purpose of the research of Neolithic sites in southwestern Asia has been to identify innovative theoretical approaches to investigate how these first large, permanently co-resident communities functioned, and how and why they networked with each other.

tiles.headline: The Hellespont Project
tiles.text: The Hellespont Project combines the digital collections of Greek and Roman antiquities of the Perseus Digital Library and the German Archaeological Institute with text using the metadata format CIDOC.
